subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] And now for something completely different.
msgSnippet: Tim, I am an old-timer in Shaw s alphabet and will give my opinion.  Stay with Shaw s if you want an accurate pronunciation of how an English speaker speaks
messageBody:
Tim,
I am an old-timer in Shaw's alphabet and will give my opinion.  Stay with Shaw's if you want an accurate pronunciation of how an English speaker speaks English.  Or, if you want to write the correct accent to someone who who can write Shaw's the way he/she speaks.  Quikskript is not purely accurate in pronunciation.  Moreover, it is difficult to read.  I use Quikskript but I would change to a better transliteration in a heart beat.  Calligraphically, Shaw's alphabet takes the cake. I would imagine that only an alphabetic phonetic script would be acceptable such as Ben Franklyns but problem usually is that the words are not very brief.  I admire your enthusiasm about involvement in such projects and have tried my hand at it but decisions seem to paralyze one's progress.  Can you write unifon on the computer?

BTW I am interested in reading Shaw's but really have not received any info except Shaw and Poe.  Are you unable to simply write a simple ad about it for those who cannot see clearly your graphic ad about it?  How many pages does it have, dimensions, fiction or non-fiction, Why did you choose these two authors, etc.

Take care, and happy new year to you again,
Your friend,
Sid

From: Tim <rubik67@...>
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, January 5, 2013 1:15 PM
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] And now for something completely different.

 
A post from me that's actually on topic. :-) Over the past week, I've been writing messages about getting my book published. I was wondering, has anyone ever tried to get anything published in Quikscript? I first decided to publish my book because I felt that the world as a whole NEEDS to learn about how to make English spelling phonetic. I learned about Quikscript later, and later still about Unifon. I'm sure there's countless others out there, too. Although I haven't really researched Quikscript enough to become a fan of it (someone sent me the manual for it years ago, but I found it too confusing compared at the time to the simplicity of Shavian), I'd probably buy a book or two written in Quikscript, especially if it was on a subject of interest to me, but the only info I found on publication in this group was a message by tim_rice09 back on July 4th, 2006. Since I found the other groups, I was pretty impressed with the transliterated works that people posted to the files section, but so long as that's ALL that's done, phonetic spelling over all will only be seen by the general public as a pipe dream. It'll take publication for people to REALLY sit up and take notice and to build overall awareness. It doesn't really matter to me which system "wins", so long as traditional orthography ends up being the loser.
